item.title: [$] How to write Rust in the kernel: part 3
item.description: The interfaces between C and Rust in the kernel have grown over time; any non-trivial Rust driver will use a number of these. Tasks like allocating memory, dealing with immovable structures, and interacting with locks are necessary for handling most devices. There are also many subsystem-specific bindings, but the focus this time will be on an overview of the bindings that all kernel Rust code can be expected to use.
